title: QTL analyses of lineage-negative mouse bone marrow cells labeled with Sca-1 and c-Kit
abstract: Differences in the number of functionally and/or phenotypically  defined bone marrow cells in inbred mouse strains have been exploited to map quantitative trait loci (QTL) that determine the variation in cell frequency. To extend this approach to the differences in the stem/progenitor cell compartment in CBA/H and C57BL/6 mice, we have exploited the resolution of flow cytometry and the power of QTL analyses in 124 F2 mice to analyse lineage negative (Lin-) bone marrow cells according to the intensity of labelling with Sca-1 and c-Kit. In the Lin- Sca-1+ c-Kit+ enriched population six quantitative trait loci (QTL) were identified – one significant and five suggestive. Whereas previous in vitro clonogenic, LTIC-IC, CAFC day 35, and flow cytometry each identified different QTL, our approach identified the same or very similar QTL at all three loci (Chromosome 1, 17 and 18) as well as QTL on chromosomes 6 and 10. In silico analyses implicate haematopoietic stem cell homing involving Cxcr4 and Cxcl12 as being the determining pathway. The mapping of the same or very similar QTLs in independent studies using different assay(s) suggests a common genetic determinant, and thus reinforces the biological and genetic significance of the QTL.  These data also suggest that mouse bone marrow cell sub-populations can be functionally, phenotypically and genetically defined.Peer-reviewedPost-prin

To extend this approach to the differences in the stem/progenitor cell compartment in CBA/H and C57BL/6 mice, we have exploited the resolution of flow cytometry and the power of QTL analyses in 124 F2 mice to analyse lineage negative (Lin-) bone marrow cells according to the intensity of labelling with Sca-1 and c-Kit. In the Lin- Sca-1+ c-Kit+ enriched population six quantitative trait loci (QTL) were identified – one significant and five suggestive. Whereas previous in vitro clonogenic, LTIC-IC, CAFC day 35, and flow cytometry each identified different QTL, our approach identified the same or very similar QTL at all three loci (Chromosome 1, 17 and 18) as well as QTL on chromosomes 6 and 10. In silico analyses implicate haematopoietic stem cell homing involving Cxcr4 and Cxcl12 as being the determining pathway. The mapping of the same or very similar QTLs in independent studies using different assay(s) suggests a common genetic determinant, and thus reinforces the biological and genetic significance of the QTL. subject: Article
fullText:
1 
QTL analyses of lineage negative mouse bone marrow cells labelled 
with Sca-1 and c-kit 
 
 
Mays Jawad, Clare Cole, Abigail Zanker, George Giotopoulos, Simon Fitch, 
Christopher J. Talbot and Mark Plumb 
 
Department of Genetics, University of Leicester, Leicester LE1 7RH, U.K. 
 
 
Correspondence:  Chris Talbot  
Department of Genetics, University of Leicester,  
University Road, Leicester LE1 7RH, U.K. 
Tel: +44 (0)116 252 3433 
 Fax: +44 (0)116 252 3378  
E.mail: cjt14@le.ac.uk 
 
 
Running title: QTL for stem cell frequency 
Keywords:   Stem cell, quantitative trait loci, flow cytometry 
 
 2 
Abstract 
 
Differences in the number of functionally and/or phenotypically  defined bone 
marrow cells in inbred mouse strains have been exploited to map quantitative trait loci 
(QTL) that determine the variation in cell frequency. To extend this approach to the 
differences in the stem/progenitor cell compartment in CBA/H and C57BL/6 mice, we 
have exploited the resolution of flow cytometry and the power of QTL analyses in 
124 F2 mice to analyse lineage negative (Lin-) bone marrow cells according to the 
intensity of labelling with Sca-1 and c-Kit. In the Lin- Sca-1+ c-Kit+ enriched 
population six quantitative trait loci (QTL) were identified – one significant and five 
suggestive. Whereas previous in vitro clonogenic, LTIC-IC, CAFC day 35, and flow 
cytometry each identified different QTL, our approach identified the same or very 
similar QTL at all three loci (Chromosome 1, 17 and 18) as well as QTL on 
chromosomes 6 and 10. In silico analyses implicate haematopoietic stem cell homing 
involving Cxcr4 and Cxcl12 as being the determining pathway. The mapping of the 
same or very similar QTLs in independent studies using different assay(s) suggests a 
common genetic determinant, and thus reinforces the biological and genetic 
significance of the QTL.  These data also suggest that mouse bone marrow cell sub-
populations can be functionally, phenotypically and genetically defined. 
 
 3 
Introduction 
 
The regulation of haemopoiesis relies on the proliferation and/or differentiation of 
bone marrow stem and progenitor cells which have been functionally defined using 
either in vitro clonogenic assays or in vivo repopulation assays in engrafted mice. 
Significant differences in normal haematopoiesis have been reported between inbred 
mouse strains, and these differences have enabled genetic studies to identify 
quantitative trait loci (QTL) that regulate these differences. For example, QTL  that 
determine stem cell numbers (Henckaerts et al. 2002, 2004; De Haan and Van Zant 
1997, 2000,2002; Muller-Sieburg and Riblet 1996; Morrison et al. 1997, 2002), the 
frequency of progenitor cells and the relative proportion of mature blood red, T and B 
cells (Chen and Harrison 2002; Morrison et al. 2002; van Os et al. 2006;  Peters et al. 
2006; Valdar et al. 2006; Jawad et al. 2007a) have been identified. In a landmark 
study the gene underlying one of these QTL has recently been identified as latexin 
(Liang et al. 2007). Despite the hierarchical nature of haemopoiesis, there is little 
overlap in QTL that determine the frequencies of stem, progenitor and mature 
haemopoietic cells, suggesting that functionally defined mouse bone marrow cells can 
also be genetically defined. 
 
In vitro bone marrow stem and immature progenitor cell assays are based on stroma-
dependent long-term bone marrow cultures. The long-term culture initiating cell 
(LTC-IC) and Cobblestone Area Forming Cells (day 35 CAFC) have been shown to 
be related to the bone marrow repopulating stem cell in BXD RI mice (Ploemacher et 
al. 1991; Muller-Sieburg and Riblet, 1996; Sutherland et al. 1990; Petzer et al. 1996; 
Breems et al. 1994). As described in Table 1, the initial study using LTC-IC identified 
QTL on chromosome 1 (Muller-Sieburg and Riblet, 1996) and although this was 
missed in an initial CAFC Day 35 study (QTL on chromosome 18 only; de Haan and 
Van Zant, 1997), a more recent CAFC Day 35 study identified both QTL on 
chromosomes 1 and 18 (Geiger et al. 2001).  
 
Stem and progenitor cells have also been phenotypically defined according to the 
expression of specific cell surface antigens such as Sca-1 (Ly6A/E), Thy-1, c-Kit, 
CD34 and Flk-2 (Christensen and Weissman, 2001; Morrison et al. 1995, 1997; 
Okada et al. 1992; Spangrude and Brooks, 1992). They do not express lineage 
 4 
markers found in maturing blood cells (Lin-), are Thy-1.1lo and are positive for the 
expression of Sca-1 and c-Kit. For example, Lin- Thy-1.1lo Sca-1+ or Lin- CD34lo/- 
Sca-1+ c-Kit+ bone marrow cells provides stable, long-term multi-lineage 
haemopoiesis in recipient mice (Uchida and Weissman, 1992; Osawa et al. 1996). The 
QTL that determine the frequencies of LTC-IC and day 35 CAFC  are also unrelated 
to the (C57BL/Ka-Thy-1.1 X AKR/J)F2  chromosome 17 QTL that determine the 
frequency  of Lin- Thy-1.1low Sca-1+ c-Kit+ cells analysed directly by flow cytometry 
(Morrison et al. 2002; Table 1). This suggests that the assays may be examining 
different cells within the stem/progenitor cell compartment, or in the case of in vitro 
long term assays, differences in their ability to produce colonies in vitro. 
 
Although the evidence suggests that functionally defined bone marrow stem and 
progenitor cells can also be both phenotypically and genetically defined, the genetic 
relationship between apparently similar phenotypes is confused. Theoretically some if 
not all of the cells that give rise to LTC-IC and/or day 35 CAFC colonies should be 
positive for Sca-1 and c-Kit. Similarly, functionally defined LTC-IC and day 35 
CAFC should be genetically related to Lin- Thy-1.1low Sca-1+ c-Kit+ cells.  We have 
therefore analysed total Lin- Sca-1+ c-Kit+ bone marrow cells in (CBA/H x 
C57Bl/6)F2 mice directly by Fluorescence Activated Cell Scanning (FACS) and 
mapped QTL, three of which map to the same or similar chromosomal intervals that 
determine the frequency of LTC-IC (chromosome 1), day 35 CAFC (chromosome 18) 
and  Lin-, Thy-1.1low, Sca-1+, c-Kit+ (chromosome 17) cells (Muller-Sieburg and 
Riblet, 1996; de Haan and Van Zant, 1997; Morrison et al. 2002). This direct analysis 
by flow cytometry together with a genome-wide screen in F2 mice provides 
supportive evidence that functionally defined bone marrow cell sub-populations are 
also both phenotypically and genetically defined.  
 
 
Materials and Methods 
 
Mice 
 
CBA/H mice were from the Harwell colony, and C57BL/6, DBA/2 mice were from 
Harlan UK Limited. (CBA/H x C57BL/6)F1 and F2 mice were bred in Leicester.  The 
 5 
animal studies were carried out under guidance issued by the MRC in ‘Responsibility 
in the use of animals for medical research’ (July 1993) and Home Office Project 
licences No PPL 80\1565 and 80\1564.    
 
 
Flow cytometry analysis and Isolation of Primitive Haematopoietic progenitors 
 
Bone marrow was flushed from the femurs of 8-12 week old mice and depleted of 
lineage positive (Lin+) cells using streptavidin-conjugated magnetic beads (QIAGEN, 
Northampton, U.K) and a panel of biotinylated anti CD3e, CD11b, CD45R, Ly-6G 
and Ly-6C, and TER-119 antibodies. Lin–  bone marrow cells were counted (Scharfe 
System Casey 1 machine) and then labelled with R-phycoerythrin- (R-PE) conjugated 
anti mouse c-Kit and fluorescein isothiocyanate-(FITC) conjugated anti Sca-1 or 
appropriate isotype controls. All antibodies were from Becton Dickinson-Pharmingen 
(Oxford, U.K.). The whole cell population acquisition and analysis was performed on 
a two-laser FACScalibur (Becton Dickinson) and data analysed using Cellquest 
software. Individual mice were analysed.  
 
Background, autofluorescence and non-specific antibody labelling was determined 
using unlabelled bone marrow cells, or bone marrow cells labelled with appropriate 
rat IgG2 isotype controls, or single labelling with specific FITC Sca-1 or R-PE c-Kit   
antibodies.  
 
 
Genetic analysis 
 
Lin- bone marrow cells from 124 F2 mice were analysed for Sca-1 and c-Kit 
expression by flow cytometry. If necessary, quantitative data from the flow cytometer 
were normalised (by square root transformation) for QTL analysis. DNA prepared 
from the tails of the F2 mice was genotyped using 126 polymorphic microsatellite 
markers as previously described (Boulton et al. 2003) in a genome-wide screen at ~20 
cM intervals. The genotype and phenotype data for each of the 124 F2 mice were 
analysed by composite interval mapping using QTL Cartographer (Wang et al. 2001-
2004). Significance linkage levels were calculated by permuting the data 10,000 times 
 6 
and interpreted as determined by Lander and Kruglyak (1995). The calculated 
thresholds showed little variation between phenotypes, for LSK they were:  
Suggestive linkage LOD >2.5, significant linkage LOD >3.5, and highly significant 
linkage LOD > 5.8. 95% confidence intervals are based on one LOD support intervals 
(Lynch and Walsh 1998). QTL positions and effect sizes were estimated using 
multiple interval mapping. Megabase positions are based on genome build NCBI 
m36. 
 
The three quantitative traits for which QTL were found are highly correlated (R1 vs 
Lin-, Sca-1++ r=0.76; R1 vs Lin-, Sca-1-, c-Kit- r=-0.65; Lin-, Sca-1++ vs Lin-, Sca-1-, 
c-Kit- r=-0.78) as expected, so no adjustment of significance thresholds was used. 
 
 
In silico analysis 
 
Candidate genes in the QTL were assessed against four criteria. Firstly, we 
interrogated the GeneNetwork database (www.genenetwork.org) for genes showing 
cis-regulation of expression in the QTL (Liang et al. 2007, Bystrykh et al. 2005), 
using data from the GNF haematopoietic cells on Affymetrix microarray U74Av2 for 
the BXD cross. Secondly, we searched the GNF SymAtlas 
(http://symatlas.gnf.org/SymAtlas/) for genes showing bone marrow expression 
greater than 3-fold the tissue median, which again uses data from Affymetrix U74 
arrays (Su et al. 2004). Thirdly we searched the Mouse Genome Database for genes 
with mutants known to have haematopoietic phenotypes (Eppig et al, 2005). Fourthly 
the strain distribution patterns of SNPs across the loci were compared for the strains 
in the cross (data from Scripps Florida Mouse Database and WTCHG (Cervino et al, 
2006; Valdar et al, 2006)) to identify chromosomal regions of divergent ancestry. 
 7 
 
 
Results 
 
Parental CBA/H and C57BL/6 mice 
 
To enumerate the frequency of Lin- cells according to the intensity of Sca-1 and/or c-
Kit labelling in the parental CBA/H and C57BL/6 inbred mouse strains, Lin- bone 
marrow cells were isolated by immunomagnetic depletion of the Lin+ cells. There was 
no significant difference in the recovery of total non-erythroid bone marrow cells 
(WBMC) or Lin- cells (~3% of WBMC) from the two inbred mouse strains or the 
(CBA/H x C57BL/6)F1 hybrid (Jawad et al, 2007a). The Lin- cells were labelled with 
FITC anti-Sca-1 and PE anti-c-Kit antibodies and all cells visualised by flow 
cytometry.  
 
Gating strategy was selected such that >98% of unlabelled Lin-  bone marrow cells 
appeared in the 30 x 30 lower left cytogram quadrant and therefore positive 
fluorescent events were classified as events in the >30 quadrant limit (Figure 1A). 
Similar results were obtained using FITC and R-PE conjugated isotype control 
antibodies (data not shown). The labelling of Lin- bone marrow cells with single R-PE 
c-Kit (Figure 1B) or FITC Sca-1 antibodies (Figure 1C) illustrate both the specificity 
of antibody binding and reinforce the 0-30 quadrant definition of unlabelled cells.  As 
shown in Figures 1A-C, there is some background and autofluorescence, but 
altogether, using unlabelled cells, isotype controls and single specific antibody 
labelling of Lin- cells, background fluorescence outside the defined 0-30 limits on the 
x and y axis was estimated as <3%.  
 
Lin- cells prepared from CBA/H (Figure 2A), C57BL/6 (Figure 2B) and DBA/2 
(Figure 2C) bone marrow labelled with both c-Kit and Sca-1 antibodies further 
illustrate the specificity of the flow cytometric analyses. Compared to C57BL/6, 
CBA/H and DBA/2 Lin- cells are enriched for a discrete subpopulation of Lin-Sca-
1+c-Kit+ cells (L-S+K+; Figure 2A and C, highlighted) and this is well above the 
background. For convenience, cells that fluoresce with an intensity of between 30 and 
102 are arbitrarily defined as (+), whereas those that fluoresce with an intensity of 
 8 
>102 are defined as (++). Thus, the cytograms can be quantitatively analysed 
according to the nine areas defined by the relative fluorescence intensity (-, + or ++, 
Figure 2D)  of the Sca-1 and c-Kit  coordinates in addition to the gated (R1) discrete 
population of Lin- Sca-1+ c-Kit+ cells (R1; Figure 2D).  
 
As shown in Table 2, there is a statistically significant genotype-dependent difference 
in the frequency of the discrete subpopulation of gated L-S+K+ cells (p = 0.0054).  It is 
worthy of note that the frequency of all Sca-1 positive cells that fluoresce intensely (y 
> 102; highlighted Figure 2B) is higher in C57BL/6 and DBA/2 than CBA/H. This is 
consistent with C57BL/6 mice that carry the Ly6b haplotype giving higher Sca-1 
expression than the Ly6a haplotype of the CBA/H mice (Spangrude and Brooks, 
1993). Also, the frequency of Sca-1+ cells in F1 hybrid mice are similar to the 
C57BL/6 mice, suggesting that the higher intensity of the Sca-1+ cells is determined 
by a dominant C57BL/6 genetic train (data not shown). Despite the Ly-6 haplotypes, 
CBA/H (and DBA/2) mice have a ~4 fold higher frequency of the discrete L-S+K+ 
cells than C57BL/6 mice. CBA/H mice are closely related to DBA/2 mice (Festing 
1996), and the four-fold L-S+K+ cell frequency difference is the same order of 
magnitude as the higher frequency of stem cells in DBA/2 and CBA mice compared 
to C57BL/6 mice estimated using in vitro LTC-IC (Muller-Sieberg and Riblet 1996) 
and/or day 35 CAFC (de Haan and Van Zant 1997) in vitro clonogenic assays. 
 
Despite the observed difference in the intensity/number of Sca-1+/++ cells between the 
two parental strains, there is less of a difference in the total number of Lin- Sca-1++ c-
Kit++ (Upper right quadrant in Figure 2D) cells between the two inbred strains, the 
difference is not statistically significant and both are comparable to that observed in 
the F1 hybrid (data not shown). This is due in part to the observed higher frequency of 
the discrete R1 L-S+K+ gated population (Table 2) in CBA/H mice than C57BL/6 
mice, indicating that reduced difference in the total number of Lin- Sca-1++ c-Kit++ 
cells is a balance between higher Sca-1 labelling in the C57BL/6 mice and a higher 
frequency of the gated R1 (L-S+K+) cells in CBA/H mice. 
 
 9 
Genetic analysis 
 
Lin- bone marrow cells from each of 124 (CBA/H X C57BL/6)F1 intercross F2 mice 
were analysed for Sca-1 and c-Kit labelling by flow cytometry, and genotyped in a 
genome wide screen at ~20 cM intervals with 126 polymorphic microsatellite 
markers. Quantitative data for each mouse and FACS area (Figure 2D) were analysed 
using the QTL Cartographer programme (Wang et al. 2001-2004). Areas of the flow 
cytogram that revealed genetic linkage above the threshold necessary for suggestive 
linkage, as calculated by permuting the data (LOD= 2.5), are summarised in Table 3 
(Lander and Kruglyak 1995). As the quantitative traits used are correlated no 
correction was applied for multiple testing.  
 
Composite interval mapping found a significant QTL on chromosome 17 that 
determines the frequency of double negative L-S-K- cells, which maps to the HLA 
locus (Figure 5 and Table 3). Analysis of the same L-S-K- cells identified a suggestive 
QTL on chromosome 19. No QTL were revealed for Lin- c-Kit+ cells (x > 30), but a 
significant QTL on chromosome 15 was revealed for the intensely labelling Lin- Sca-
1+ cells (Lin-Sca-1++; y >102; Figures 2 & 4 and Table 3).  The mouse Sca-1 gene 
maps to chromosome 15 so this result is consistent with the known Ly-6 haplotypes of 
the parental mouse strains (Spangrude and Brooks 1993). 
 
Five QTL were revealed for the discrete population of L-S+K+ cells, four of which 
achieve the criteria of suggestive (LOD > 2.5; chromosomes 6 and 17, 18), and one is 
significant (LOD 3.5, chromosome 10) (Table 3 and Figure 3). Optimisation of final 
QTL models by Multiple Interval Mapping reveals an additional QTL on 
chromosome 1 at 62cM (an epistatic effect with the chromosome 17 QTL) and 
estimates the effect sizes of the QTL as being: chromosome 1 4.8%, chromosome 6 
5.0% and 8.1%, chromosome 10 10.8%, chromosome 17 5.1%, chromosome 18 6.7%. 
 
Two of the QTL map close to QTL that determine the frequency of stem cells in 
(BXD)RI mice using the LTC-IC (Scfr2, chromosome 1; ~53 cM)(Muller-Sieburg 
and Riblet 1996) and day 35 CAFC (chromosome 18; 19 cM) (de Haan and Van Zant, 
1997)  in vitro clonogenic stem cell assays (Table 1). The chromosome 17 QTL (HLA 
complex) was also revealed by flow cytometry of Lin- Thy-1low Sca-1+ c-Kit+ (AKR/J 
 10 
x C57Bl/Ka)F2 bone marrow cells (Morrison et al. 2002). Interestingly, the 
chromosome 15 (Ly6) QTL was not revealed in the analysis of the discrete population 
of Lin- Sca-1+ c-Kit+ cells (Table 3). 
 
There is no evidence of a sex effect in these data; none of the traits are significantly 
different between males and females and introducing sex as a co-variate in the QTL 
analysis makes little difference (data not shown). 
 
 
 
 
 
In silico analysis 
 
Each QTL contains many genes but in silico analyses were carried out to compile a 
list of candidate quantitative trait genes (QTG). To assess the specificity of our 
criteria we scored all protein-coding genes on mouse chromosome 2, for which no 
QTL were detected. Of the 1913 protein-coding genes 2.0% show cis regulation of 
transcription, 4.8% have bone marrow expression >3-fold above median and 4.1% 
have mutants with known haematopoietic phenotypes. Only one chromosome 2 gene 
(Cd44) meets all three of these criteria, and it also meets the fourth criterion, by being 
in a genomic region with SNPs informative for this cross. Thus although these criteria 
will miss candidate QTG e.g. those not present on the Affymetrix U74 microarrays, 
they are fairly specific, given that the QTL intervals each contain around 300 genes. 
 
In the chromosome 1 QTL only the Cxcr4 gene meets all four criteria, with no other 
gene meeting more than two (see methods). In the distal chromosome 6 QTL there are 
two candidates that meet three criteria: Cxcl2 and Cdca3. For the chromosome 10 
QTL three genes met two of the criteria: integrin b2, thymopoietin and Spi-C. For the 
chromosome 18 QTL the candidate genes are FGF1 and desmoglein-2 (2 criteria 
each). There are no candidates that meet more than one criterion for the other QTL. 
Given that previous QTL have been mapped to similar regions as found in this study 
using different in vitro assays, our data thus provide genetic evidence for the presence 
of the LTC-IC and day 35 CAFC cells in the discrete population of L-S+K+ cells that 
 11 
can be directly visualised by flow cytometry irrespective of the Ly-6 haplotype of the 
parental mouse strains. In addition to being phenotypically defined (Lin- Sca-1+ c-
Kit+), the genetic evidence are strong supportive evidence that they are enriched for 
functionally defined stem cells. 
 
 
Discussion 
 
We have combined the power of mouse genetics with the discrimination of flow 
cytometry to map QTL that control the frequency of specific sub-populations of 
lineage negative bone marrow cells separated according to c-Kit and/or Sca-1 
labelling and that can be directly visualised irrespective of the Ly-6 haplotype. The 
QTL on chromosomes 1 (62 cM) and 18 (13.1 cM) that determine the frequency of a 
discrete population of L-S+K+ (R1) cells are the same or very similar to the QTL that 
regulate the frequency of LTC-IC (~50 cM; p= 0.0007) (Muller-Sieburg and Riblet 
1996), and day 35 CAFC (19 cM; LOD 3.3) (de Haan and Van Zant 1997) cells in 
BXD RI mice, respectively. A third significant QTL (chromosome 17) has previously 
been implicated in the frequency of Thy-1low Sca-1+ c-Kit+ cells (Morrison et al. 
2002) and contains the mouse H-2 complex, including the Class I MHC alleles. It is 
unclear whether the same gene(s) within the MHC complex determine the frequency 
of Thy-1low Sca-1+ c-Kit+, L- S+ K+ and L- S- K- cells (Tables 1 and 3) (Morrison et al. 
2002). 
 
Genetic loci that confer a susceptibility to spontaneous or induced haemopoietic 
malignancies have also been mapped in mice, and differences in the relative 
frequency of the target cell (target size) may be one genetically determined risk factor 
(recently reviewed by Jawad et al. 2007b). For example, QTL that determine the 
susceptibility to spontaneous pre-B and T lymphomas were both mapped to proximal 
chromosome 17 (Yamada et al. 1994a, 1994b), and thus implicates the H-2 complex 
in both the regulation of bone marrow stem and progenitor cell frequencies and a 
susceptibility to spontaneous lymphoid lymphomas. Similarly, a susceptibility to 
pristane-induced plasmacytoma QTL has been mapped to a position on chromosome 
1 (54 cM)(Mock et al. 1993) that is very similar to QTL that determine the frequency 
of L-S+K+ cells (~65 cM; Table 3), the frequency of bone marrow LTC-IC cells (~50 
 12 
cM)(Muller-Sieburg and Riblet 1996) and the relative proportion of B220 B 
lymphocytes in mouse peripheral blood (Pbbcp1; 62-64 cM)(Chen and Harrison 
2002). Similarly a  QTL that confers a susceptibility to radiation-induced AML was 
mapped to distal chromosome 1 (~100 cM; Boulton et al. 2003; Jawad et al. 2006), a 
position that is very similar to the Scfr1 locus (~100 cM) that also determines the 
frequency of LTC-IC bone marrow cells (Muller-Sieburg and Riblet 1996). However, 
the distal chromosome 1 LTC-IC QTL was not revealed in this study, suggesting that 
the colonies in the LTC-IC clonogenic assay are phenotypically heterogeneous.  
 
The largest effect L-S+K+ cell QTL detected in this study, which is on chromosome 
10, may overlap with the suggestive L-S+K+ cell QTL found in van Os et al, 2006 
(32.4-50.4cM, as compared to van Os peak between 51 and 70cM). In addition the 
distal chromosome 6 QTL has a similar location to the other suggestive QTL found in 
that study (45.9-56.0cM compared with van Os peak at 51cM). 
 
Identifying candidate genes is unreliable with the large intervals found in QTL 
studies, but can be aided by in silico analysis (Flint et al. 2005). The only gene that 
met all of our criteria was Cxcr4 on chromosome 1. This gene encodes a CXC 
cytokine receptor which is essential for the homing of haematopoietic stem cells to 
the vascular stem cell niche of the bone marrow (Burger and Burkle 2007). The fact 
that candidate genes for the other QTL include Cxcl12, which is the ligand for CXCR4 
and Itgb2, an integrin involved in HSC homing to the periphery (Chavakis et al. 
2005), leads to the tempting hypothesis that genetic variation in a common HSC 
homing pathway may be important in determining stem cell numbers. This hypothesis 
must remain tentative however until confirmatory laboratory experiments have been 
carried out. 
 
The genetic intervals mapped in these studies are large, and the possibility that 
multiple QTL map to the same interval cannot be excluded. The mapping of the same 
or very similar QTL in independent studies using different assay(s), biological end-
points and/or different inbred mouse strains increases the biological and genetic 
significance of that QTL. Of all the L-S+K+ cell QTL we mapped (Table 3) on a 
CBA/H x C57BL/6 genetic background, the same or very similar QTL on 
chromosomes 1, 17 and 18 have been previously described in independent studies of 
 13 
mouse stem/progenitor cell frequency using different assays and different genetic 
backgrounds (BXD RI, and [C57BL/Ka-Thy-1.1 x AKR/J]F2) (Table 1). Although 
the L-S+K+ may not represent all the cells that have been functionally and genetically 
defined in vitro, the L-S+K+  cells are enriched for some of those cells that give rise to 
LTC-IC and/or day 35 CAFC cells. Furthermore, this suggests that specific cellular 
phenotypes themselves can also be genetically defined, and that definition can be 
further refined. A combination of functional, phenotypic and genetic definitions of 
cell sub-populations will be an invaluable resource in providing evidence as to 
whether or not distinct phenotypic assays are in fact measuring the same cell(s), and 
potentially reveal evidence of relationships between apparently dissimilar phenotypes.

Flow cytograms of Lin- cells to illustrate the background defined by the 0-30

 18 
Figure 2: 
Direct visualization of Lin- bone marrow cells labelled with anti Sca-1 and c-Kit 
antibodies by flow cytometry. 
A-C. Representative flow cytograms of Lin- bone marrow cells from (A.) CBA/H, 
(B.) C57BL/6, and (C.) DBA/2 mice labelled for Sca-1 and c-Kit expression/antibody 
binding and visualised directly by flow cytemtry.  D. Areas of the cytogram analysed 
in this study are schematically represented where the relative fluorescence intensity 
(1-30) is defined as negative (-) based on unlabelled cells, intermediate (+; 301-102) or 
high (++; >102) as shown. The discrete population of L-S+K+ cells that distinguish 
CBA/H and DBA/2 mice from C57BL/6 mice were quantitated by gating the R1 
region. 
 19 
 
 
Figure 3: 
LOD plot using number of cells in R1 gated region (L-S+K+). 
Plot showing LOD scores achieved by composite interval mapping for the L-S+K+  
cell phenotype. Axis legend: Y axis shows LOD score and X axis is genetic position 
 20 
with chromosomes indicated. Threshold lines are for suggestive linkage at LOD 2.5 
and significant at 3.5. 
 
 
Figure 4: 
LOD plot using number of Sca-1++ cells 
Plot showing LOD scores achieved by composite interval mapping for the frequency 
of Lin- Sca-1++ cells (cytogram area y >102). Axis legend: Y axis shows LOD score 
and X axis is genetic position with chromosomes indicated. Threshold lines are for 
suggestive linkage at LOD 2.5 and significant at 3.5.

Figure 5: 
LOD plot using number of L-S-K- cells 
Plot showing LOD scores achieved by composite interval mapping for the frequency 
of double negative L-S-K- cells (cytogram area x <30, y <30 ). Axis legend: Y axis 
shows LOD score and X axis is genetic position with chromosomes indicated. 
Threshold lines are for suggestive linkage at LOD 2.5 and significant at 3.5.
